item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“jaruanna, post:9, topic:433498”]Ohh, i didn’t see the function being called. But then what is the return true for?

do you have to return true everytime you call a boolean?[/quote]

Well, yes, in a way.

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Wait, are you referring to incredibly basic simple function calling? Then yea, of course, the animation is done by the teleport() method which is being called. Functions inside a function, OOP? The return statement breaks out of a function and returns a value. The return statement in a boolean is just returning the values true and false (as it is a boolean, right?). Simple, no?

Unless I am still missing your point/question…

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @jaruanna jaruanna
item.description:
@jaruanna wrote:

Well, i was assuming since it doesn’t show a gfx and the message where this code is:

case 2452: // Air altar ruins if (x == 2984 && y == 3291) { if (itemID == 1438) { teleport(player, 2842, 4828); return true; } }
It takes it from this code:

public static boolean teleport(final Player player, final int x, final int y) { player.playAnimation(TELEPORT_ANIMATION); player.getActionSender().sendMessage("You feel a powerful force take hold of you..."); World.getWorld().submit(new Event(1200) { public void execute() { player.setTeleportTarget(Location.create(x, y, 0)); this.stop(); } }); return true; }
because in game it shows the gfx and the message.

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

I don’t see how the return statement is any useful in this case… just for programming readability?

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @jaruanna jaruanna
item.description:
@jaruanna wrote:

I’m sorry the title was mislead. I meant the return statements. When you say return true, how does the statement know to teleport someone somewhere or send a message to them. Here’s another example:

case 2452: // Air altar ruins if (x == 2984 && y == 3291) { if (itemID == 1438) { teleport(player, 2842, 4828); return true; } }

you see where it returns true? How does it know to return this:

public static boolean teleport(final Player player, final int x, final int y) { player.playAnimation(TELEPORT_ANIMATION); player.getActionSender().sendMessage("You feel a powerful force take hold of you..."); World.getWorld().submit(new Event(1200) { public void execute() { player.setTeleportTarget(Location.create(x, y, 0)); this.stop(); } }); return true; }

Again, im sorry for misleading title and misleading examples. They sucked…

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

A Boolean can only have two values. True or False…
try this

public static void hi() {
  boolean test = true;
   if (test != false) {
      sendMessage("Yoooo");
      return;
   } else {
      return;
   }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

No that’s not correct.
Booleans return a true/false value. Nothing more.

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“jaruanna, post:1, topic:433498”]So I haven’t really got how to use the boolean method. After looking at codes i came to this conclusion and i would like to know if it is correct.

So let’s say you have a basic method:

public boolean hi() { sendMessage("HI"); return; }

So that is the default message, im assuming. So lets say when you do something like:

if (playerhasItem(1)) { return true; } return false;

Saying that if you have that item, it will return the message hi. Is this correct?
If you can’t understand i’m sorry.[/quote]

I think, or it may be:

if (playerhasItem(1)) {
return true;
} else }
return false;

Read full topic

item.title: Return help
item.dc:creator: @jaruanna jaruanna
item.description:
@jaruanna wrote:

So I haven’t really got how to use the boolean method. After looking at codes i came to this conclusion and i would like to know if it is correct.

So let’s say you have a basic method:

public boolean hi() { sendMessage("HI"); return; }

So that is the default message, im assuming. So lets say when you do something like:

if (playerhasItem(1)) { return true; } return false;

Saying that if you have that item, it will return the message hi. Is this correct?
If you can’t understand i’m sorry.

Read full topic
